doc.title: Multiple acquisitions and maturities likely to prompt debt raising, maintain 28s at Underweight
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/HY Research SJM Holdings Multiple acquisitions and maturities likely to prompt debt raising maintain 28s at UWHY Researc_2025-08-29

passages.text: Indicated at \(6.4\%\) YTW, SJMHOL 28s appear to be unattractive versus the China HY corporate sector's average of \(7.3\%\) considering its slower- than- expected pace of deleveraging, multiple acquisition plans and EBITDA weakness on fierce competition.

SJM's HKD529mn acquisition of part of Hotel Lisboa marks a strategic move to expand its self- operated gaming footprint ahead of satellite casino closures. While the transaction supports long- term consolidation, multiple acquisitions and staggered maturities may prompt further debt raising, especially amid weak earnings and potential renovation disruptions in its properties in Macau Peninsula. We estimate these announced acquisitions (including satellite casinos and the Hengqin hotel) and maturities could reach USD1.1- 1.3bn (Figure 1), versus its existing liquidity of USD825mn. Although management reiterated strong bank support and no plans to raise equity on the 2Q25 earnings call, we believe bond issuance remains a viable option if HIBOR- financing cost rises or longer- tenor bonds become reasonably priced.

A rating downgrade appears unlikely, despite SJM's deleveraging trajectory being derailed, as Fitch has extended the downgrade threshold horizon to 2027. Valuation remains reasonable, in our view, particularly if a high proportion of the acquired area is allocated for gaming. The satellite casino acquisitions are expected to close by year- end. As a reference, convertible bonds were issued when SJM acquired Oceanus building from its major shareholder STDM in 2022. 2

2Q25 adjusted EBITDA of HKD688mn declined by \(28\%\) q/q, or \(21\%\) y/y. 1H25 adjusted EBITDA declined by \(6.1\%\) y/y to HKD1.6bn, reaching \(79\%\) of the 2019 level, mainly due to 1.2pp q/q declining market share to \(12.3\%\) . In particular, its new flagship property, GLP, recorded a HKD67mn loss in adjusted EBITDA in 2Q25, making 1H25 adjusted EBITDA tumble by \(57\%\) y/y to

Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 5.

HKD82mn. Adjusted for hold, GLP's EBITDA would have been HKD156mn in 1H25. Meanwhile, its daily opex increased \(4 - 5\%\) y/y mainly due to marketing & staff tied to satellite casinos. While management does not anticipate further growth, we believe SJM must revamp its marketing strategy to counter intensifying competition and halt its market share decline.

Gross leverage weakened to 7.7x as at the end of June 2025, versus 7.4x at end- 2024 (versus 2019 at 3.6x). Net leverage rose to 7.1x as at the end of June 2025, versus 6.8x at end- 2024 (versus 2019 at 0.2x). As at the end of June 2025, we estimate that total debt (after adding the equity component of the convertible bonds and lease liabilities) amounted to HKD28.5bn. It had total cash (including pledged deposits) of HKD3.3bn and undrawn facilities of HKD3.1bn.

By the end of 2024, short- term debts of HKD9bn consisted of bank loans of HKD3.4bn and three bonds with a combined total of HKD5.5bn- equivalence due in 1H26. SJM purchased USD8mn SJMhOL 28s and cancelled them on 28 January 2025, which has reduced the outstanding size to USD482mn.

As a reference, the financing cost is 1- month HIBOR/MAIBOR + 1.25- 2.25% for secured GLP bank loans, and 1- month HIBOR + 2.5% for secured P16 bank loans. Given SJM's acquisitions and maturities ahead, we believe besides loan financing, bond issuance remains a possibility if HIBOR rises or longer tenors of bonds become affordable, while the company has ruled out the possibility of raising equity.
FIGURE 1. SJM's existing liquidity is insufficient to fund upcoming acquisitions and maturities

Note: only bond maturities in 2026 are included for our analysis Source: Company data, Barclays Research

On 28 August 2025, SJM announced a HKD529mn acquisition of part of Hotel Lisboa from its controlling shareholder STDM, so as to expand its self- operated gaming area in Casino Lisboa. In particular, management plans to reallocate 25- 35% of 458 tables from the satellite casinos scheduled to close by year- end, to the incremental gaming property space in the acquisition.
The purchase is expected complete on or before 31 December 2025, according to the announcement.3

The acquisition price of HKD529mn is significantly higher than the seller's book value at HKD36because the property had been completed decades ago. The original cost of the propens isn't available because Hotel Lisboa, which includes the part of property that is going to be developed by the seller.

We estimate an implied ASP of HKD70k per sqm, based on the HKD529 million acquisition price for 7,504 sqm of Hotel Lisboa (which represents 6% of the total floor area of the hotel). While this is higher than the HKD49k per sqm paid for the Oceanus building in 2022, the premium may be justified if a larger portion of the acquired space is used for gaming. Management plans to reallocate 25-35% of 458 satellite casino tables to this area.

Assuming 30% of the 458 tables are moved and each table requires 35 sqm, the gaming area would total 4,800 sqm (64%), with the remaining 2,700 sqm (36%) for non-gaming. This compares favorably to Oceanus, where only 35% of the area was gaming-related.
After applying Oceanus's segmented ASPs, we estimate the fair value of the Hotel Lisboa acquisition at HKD546 million, broadly in line with the proposed price.
SJM plans to fund this acquisition by the internal resources and/or existing banking facilities.

Source: Company data, Barclays Research

While we acknowledge the bond's supportive technicals, the 6.4% YTW appears unattractive versus the China HY corporate sector's average of 7.3%, considering its slower-than-expected pace of deleveraging, multiple acquisition plans and EBITDA weakness on fierce competition. In particular, we believe the company's earlier target of reaching 5.5x net leverage is unlikely to be achieved. However, rating downgrade risk appears to be low in near term because Fitch thinks the potential acquisitions are unlikely to significantly affect SJM's credit profile, and it has relaxed its rating downgrade trigger of 5x net leverage to 2027, from 2026 previously.4 We expect its leverage to remain higher than Melco in near term.
Upside risks: Better-than-expected increase in market share and GLP performance, resolution of satellite casinos, faster-than-expected deleveraging, and new financing.
3 SJM: Connected transaction in relation to the acquisition of the property in Hotel Lisboa, HKEX, 28 August 2025
4 Fitch Affirms SJM Holdings at 'BB-'; Outlook Stable, 24 December 2024
FIGURE 3. Relative values of HY Macau gaming bonds and Resort World Las Vegas (RWLVCA)

SJMHOL 4.85 01/27/28, Underweight (USD 97.25, 27- Aug- 2025)
Valuation Methodology: Unattractive valuations versus averages for the China HY Corp sector.

Risks that May Impede Achievement of the Rating: Upside risk: Better- than- expected increase in market share and GLP performance, resolution of satellite casinos, faster- than- expected deleveraging, and new financing.

Sectors in U.S. High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield \(2\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield \(2\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index.
Sectors in European High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index.

Sectors in Industrials and Utilities in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield \(3\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield \(3\%\) Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials.

Sectors in Financials in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index.

Sectors in Asia High Grade Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index. Sectors in Asia High Yield Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index.

Sectors in EEMEA and Latin America Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. These sectors may contain both High Grade and High Yield issuers.

Overweight (Ow): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the debt security subject to this rating to exceed the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Market Weight (MW): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the debt security subject to this rating to be in line with the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Underweight (UW): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the rated debt security subject to this rating to be less than the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.

This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market.
